Name: Jhilinga Tihar
Description: Jhilinga Tihar is a traditional Nepali dish made during festivals, featuring a unique blend of spices and ingredients that create a rich and flavorful treat.
RecipeInstructions: In a large bowl, soak the lentils overnight. Next day, rinse the soaked lentils thoroughly. If no outer skin of the lentils is desired, you can rub the soaked lentils between your palms and the outer skin will wash off.
Transfer the washed lentils to a large blender, add a small amount of water, and blend it into a thick paste.

Transfer the lentil mixture to a large mixing bowl. Add the oil, minced garlic, ginger, and green chilies. Add turmeric, asafoetida, and salt and pepper. Add the beaten eggs and ground meat. Combine the lentil mixture thoroughly. At this point, it is better to store the lentil mixture in the refrigerator for a couple of hours to allow for the flavors to fuse.

For cooking, heat 2 tablespoons of cooking oil in a non-stick, thick-bottomed pan or tawa under medium heat. Pour a half cup of the lentil mixture onto the pan and gently spread the mixture into the shape of a mini-pancake. Repeat with other patties, ensuring not to overcrowd the pan so that you can turn over the patties more easily.

Cook the patties on one side until the edges have crisped up and the patties themselves have attained a golden brown color. Turn the patties over onto the other side and cook until the patties have cooked and are golden brown. You can use paper towels to remove any excess oil if required.
Transfer to a serving dish and serve hot with mango chutney or any other condiment.
It is also common to add an egg topping or a minced meat topping or whatever toppings you desire.

For convenience, an alternative to cooking your baras in a pan is using a waffle machine. For this, heat up your waffle machine and using oil spray coat the top and bottom surfaces. Pour a half cup of the lentil mixture on the bottom surface, gently spread out the mixture, and close the lid to cook. Cook until the lentil patty is cooked and has attained a golden brown color, approximately 5-7 minutes. Baking is another healthy way to cook baras.

Name: Veli Roti
Description: Veli Roti is a traditional Nepali flatbread often made during festivals. It's a delicious, slightly sweet bread with a unique texture, perfect for pairing with a variety of dishes or enjoyed on its own.
RecipeInstructions: In a large bowl, combine rice flour, sugar, and salt. Gradually add water while stirring until you achieve a smooth batter consistency.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat and lightly grease it with ghee or oil.
Pour a ladleful of the batter onto the pan and spread it out into a thin, even layer. Cook for a few minutes until the edges start to lift and the bottom is golden brown.
Flip the roti and cook the other side for a couple more minutes until it’s golden brown and cooked through.
Remove from the pan and keep warm. Repeat with the remaining batter, greasing the pan as needed.
Serve warm with curry, yogurt, or enjoy as a sweet treat.

Name: Fini Roti
Description: Fini Roti is a traditional Nepali flatbread often enjoyed during festivals or special occasions. It has a slightly sweet flavor and is typically served warm.
RecipeInstructions: In a large bowl, combine the rice flour, wheat flour (if using), sugar, and salt.

Gradually add water to the dry ingredients, mixing continuously until a smooth, slightly thick batter forms. The consistency should be similar to pancake batter. If the mixture is too thick, add a little more water.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat. Lightly grease it with a little ghee or oil.
Pour a ladleful of the batter onto the pan and spread it out into a thin, even layer using the back of the ladle. The roti should be about 1/8 inch thick.
Cook for 2-3 minutes on one side until the edges start to lift and the bottom is golden brown. Flip and cook the other side until golden brown.
Remove from the pan and keep warm. Repeat with the remaining batter, greasing the pan as needed.
Serve warm with your favorite curry or enjoy as a sweet treat on its own.

Name: Kheer
Description: Kheer is a traditional Nepali rice pudding made with milk, rice, sugar, and flavored with cardamom, saffron, and nuts. It's a popular dessert often served during festivals and special occasions.
RecipeInstructions: In a heavy-bottomed pan, bring the milk to a boil over medium heat. Stir occasionally to prevent scorching.
Add the rice to the boiling milk and reduce the heat to low. Let the rice cook in the milk, stirring occasionally to prevent sticking.
Once the rice is cooked and the mixture has thickened, add the sugar, cardamom, saffron, and nuts. Stir well to combine.
Continue to cook the kheer on low heat until it reaches your desired consistency. If the kheer becomes too thick, you can add more milk to adjust the consistency.
Remove the kheer from heat and let it cool slightly. Garnish with more nuts and raisins before serving.
Serve the kheer warm or chilled, depending on your preference. Enjoy this creamy and flavorful dessert as a sweet ending to your meal.
Note: You can adjust the sweetness of the kheer by adding more or less sugar according to your taste.

Name: Tilko Laddu
Description: Tilko Laddu is a traditional Nepali sweet made from sesame seeds and jaggery, often enjoyed during festivals like Makar Sankranti. It has a delightful nutty flavor and is a popular treat during celebrations.
RecipeInstructions: Roast the sesame seeds in a dry pan over medium heat until they are golden brown and aromatic. Set aside to cool.

In a separate pan, heat ghee over medium heat. Add jaggery and a small amount of water (just enough to dissolve the jaggery) and cook until it reaches a soft-ball stage (approximately 110°C or 230°F).
Add the roasted sesame seeds to the jaggery syrup and mix well. If using, add a pinch of cardamom powder for additional flavor.
Remove from heat and let the mixture cool slightly until it is safe to handle.
Grease your hands with a little ghee and shape the mixture into small balls or laddu while it is still warm.
Allow the laddus to cool completely and harden before storing in an airtight container.

Name: Yomari
Description: Yomari is a traditional Nepali dumpling made from steamed dough filled with a mixture of jaggery and sesame seeds. It's a popular treat during the festival of Yomari Punhi.
RecipeInstructions: In a mixing bowl, combine all-purpose flour and a pinch of salt. Gradually add water and knead into a smooth, pliable dough. Cover and set aside to rest.
In a separate bowl, mix jaggery and sesame seeds until well combined. If the jaggery is too hard, you can soften it by heating it gently.

Divide the dough into small balls. Flatten each ball into a round disc, place a small amount of the jaggery and sesame seed mixture in the center, and fold the edges over to form a dumpling shape. Pinch the edges to seal the filling inside.
Grease a steamer basket with a little ghee or oil. Place the dumplings in the steamer, making sure they don’t touch each other.
Steam the dumplings over boiling water for about 15-20 minutes, or until the dough is cooked and the filling is melted and gooey.
Allow the Yomari to cool slightly before serving. Enjoy warm or at room temperature.

Name: Gundruk (Fermented Leafy Greens)
Description: Gundruk is a traditional Nepali fermented leafy green vegetable dish, often served as a side dish or used in soups and curries. It has a tangy, slightly sour flavor that is unique to Nepali cuisine.
RecipeInstructions: Wash and chop the mustard leaves (or spinach) into large pieces.
Boil the chopped leaves in water for a few minutes until slightly tender. Drain and set aside to cool.
Once cooled, transfer the boiled leaves into a clean, airtight container. Press down to remove any air pockets. Add salt and a small amount of water, just enough to cover the leaves.
Leave the container in a warm place for 5-7 days to allow fermentation. The leaves will develop a sour, tangy flavor.
Once fermented, heat oil in a pan and sauté garlic, onion, and green chilies until fragrant.
Add the fermented gundruk to the pan and stir-fry for a few minutes. Adjust salt to taste.
Serve as a side dish with rice or incorporate into soups or curries.

Name: Pulao
Description: Pulao is a fragrant rice dish popular across South Asia, made with basmati rice, vegetables, and aromatic spices. It's a versatile dish, often served as a main or side with yogurt, chutney, or curry.
RecipeInstructions: Rinse the basmati rice thoroughly and soak it in water for 20 minutes. Drain and set aside.
Heat oil or ghee in a large pan. Add cumin seeds, bay leaf, cloves, and cinnamon, and sauté until aromatic.
Add sliced onions and cook until golden brown.
Stir in turmeric, garam masala, and salt. Add the mixed vegetables and cook for 2-3 minutes.
Add the drained rice to the pan and stir gently to combine with the spices and vegetables.
Pour 2 cups of water into the pan, bring it to a boil, and then cover with a lid. Reduce heat to low and cook for 15-20 minutes or until the rice is fully cooked and water is absorbed.
Fluff the rice with a fork and serve hot.

Name: Lalmohan (Gulab Jamun)
Description: Lalmohan, also known as Gulab Jamun, is a popular Nepali and South Asian dessert made from fried dough balls soaked in sugar syrup. It’s soft, syrupy, and full of flavor, usually enjoyed during festivals or special occasions.
RecipeInstructions: In a mixing bowl, combine milk powder, all-purpose flour, and baking soda.
Add ghee and mix. Slowly add milk to form a smooth dough. Let it rest for 10 minutes.
Divide the dough into small, smooth balls, ensuring there are no cracks.
Heat oil in a deep pan on low-medium heat and fry the dough balls until golden brown, stirring gently for even cooking. Remove and set aside.
In a separate pot, prepare the sugar syrup by boiling water, sugar, and cardamom powder. Add saffron if desired. Boil until the sugar dissolves completely.
Immerse the fried dough balls in the hot sugar syrup and let them soak for at least 2 hours.
Serve the Lalmohan warm or at room temperature, garnished with nuts if desired.

Name: Mutton Ghinti
Description: Mutton Ghinti is a traditional Nepali delicacy made with minced goat internal organs, such as liver, kidney, and heart, wrapped in goat intestines. This savory and flavorful dish is often enjoyed as a special treat during festivals or gatherings.
RecipeIngredientParts: 500 grams mixed goat internal organs (liver, kidney, heart), cleaned and minced
Goat intestines (cleaned and soaked in saltwater)
RecipeInstructions: Clean the goat intestines thoroughly, and soak them in saltwater for at least 1 hour. Rinse and set aside.
Heat oil in a pan over medium heat. Add chopped onions and sauté until golden brown.
Add garlic, ginger, and green chilies. Cook until fragrant and slightly golden.
Stir in turmeric powder, cumin powder, coriander powder, red chili powder, and salt. Cook for 2 minutes.
Add minced internal organs and cook, stirring occasionally, until they are fully cooked and the mixture starts to release oil.
Add garam masala and fresh coriander leaves, mixing well.
Remove from heat and let the mixture cool slightly.
Stuff the prepared goat intestines with the cooked organ mixture, ensuring they are evenly filled. Tie the ends securely with kitchen twine.
Heat a large pot of water and bring it to a boil. Gently place the stuffed intestines into the boiling water and cook for 30-40 minutes, or until they are fully cooked and firm.
Remove from the water and let cool slightly before slicing into pieces.
Serve hot with a side of spicy chutney or pickles.

Name: Chyangra Chhoila
Description: Chyangra Chhoila is a traditional Nepali dish made from spiced and grilled Himalayan goat meat. This flavorful and aromatic dish is popular in Nepal and is often enjoyed with a side of achar (pickle) or traditional drinks.
RecipeIngredientParts: 500 grams Himalayan goat meat (chyangra), cut into cubes
RecipeInstructions: In a large bowl, combine Himalayan goat meat (chyangra) with turmeric powder, cumin powder, coriander powder, red chili powder, garam masala, soy sauce, lemon juice, and salt. Mix well to coat the meat evenly. Let it marinate for at least 1 hour, preferably overnight.
Preheat a grill or oven to medium-high heat. Thread the marinated goat meat onto skewers or place it on a grilling rack.
Grill the meat for 20-25 minutes, turning occasionally, until it is cooked through and has a nice charred exterior.
Heat oil in a pan over medium heat. Add chopped onions and cook until golden brown.
Add the grilled goat meat to the pan and toss with the cooked onions. Cook for an additional 5 minutes to combine the flavors.
Garnish with fresh coriander leaves, sliced green chilies, and sesame seeds if desired.
Serve hot with achar (pickle) and a side of traditional Nepali drinks.

Name: Fokso Fry
Description: Fokso Fry is a flavorful Nepali dish made with spiced and fried goat lungs. This dish is known for its rich taste and crispy texture, often enjoyed as a hearty appetizer or side dish with a variety of accompaniments.
RecipeIngredientParts: 500 grams goat lungs (fokso), cleaned and cut into pieces
RecipeInstructions: Clean the goat lungs thoroughly and cut into bite-sized pieces.

In a large bowl, combine the lung pieces with turmeric powder, cumin powder, coriander powder, red chili powder, garam masala, soy sauce, lemon juice, and salt. Mix well to coat the meat evenly. Let it marinate for at least 1 hour, preferably overnight.
Heat oil in a large pan over medium heat. Add chopped onions and sauté until golden brown.
Add ginger-garlic paste to the pan and cook for 2 minutes until aromatic.
Add the marinated lung pieces and cook, stirring occasionally, until they are browned on all sides and cooked through, about 25-30 minutes.
If desired, add sliced green chilies and sesame seeds during the last 5 minutes of cooking for extra flavor and crunch.
Garnish with fresh coriander leaves.
Serve hot as an appetizer or side dish with your choice of accompaniments.

Name: Juju Dhau
Description: Juju Dhau is a traditional Nepali yogurt known for its creamy texture and slightly tangy flavor. Made with high-quality milk and a natural fermentation process, this yogurt is a staple in Newari cuisine and is often enjoyed as a dessert or side dish.
RecipeIngredientParts: 2 tablespoons plain yogurt (as a starter culture)
RecipeInstructions: Heat the milk in a large pan over medium heat until it starts to boil. Stir frequently to prevent burning.
Remove the pan from heat and let the milk cool to a lukewarm temperature (about 110°F or 45°C).
In a small bowl, mix the plain yogurt (starter culture) with a little warm milk to make a smooth paste.
Stir the yogurt paste into the lukewarm milk, mixing gently but thoroughly.

Cover the pan with a clean cloth or plastic wrap and let it sit in a warm, draft-free place for 8-12 hours, or until it has thickened and set. The fermentation time may vary depending on the ambient temperature.
Once set, you can stir in sugar and cardamom powder if desired for added flavor.
Refrigerate the yogurt for a few hours before serving. Serve chilled as a dessert or side dish.
